author: barnabemonnot
content: iiuc, it's more a latency game than a timing game. Builders co-locating with relays can make fresher bids, which the relay can serve to the proposers as fast as possible. It's independent from the proposer's decision to make a late call or not to the relay.

author: terence0083
content: In this scenario, there is an additional step, `Builder -> Relayer`. Indeed, the Nash equilibrium here is the vertical integration of builder-relayer scheme. If we consider that economies of scale make it more efficient for 100 builders to vertically integrate with one relayer, then I agree with this argument. However, I also believe that builders can collaborate or employ professional proxy services as needed to quickly handle get header requests in epbs. This maintains the same advantages as current systems without diminishing trust.

author: terence0083
content: A reasonable argument against epbs is that it may completely lose bid transparency. At least, I am not sure how to replicate the same service in epbs. For reference, there's a website (https://bidarchive.relayscan.io/index.html) that archives all bids using 3-4 resources
